Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award, the Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Chemistry Division is funding Dr. Sarah Michel from the University of Maryland-Baltimore to study the mechanism of action and key structure/function relationships for three "non-classical" zinc finger (ZF) proteins, (1) the Cleavage and Polyadenylation and Stimulating Factor (CPSF30), which plays a central role in pre-mRNA processing in all eukaryotes, and (2) the Neural Zinc Finger Factor-1 (NZF-1) and related (3) Myelin Transcription Factor 1 (MyT1), which play critical roles in the development of the central nervous system (CNS). A biochemical and biophysical approach will be taken to characterize the Zn(II) binding domains of CPSF30 and identify the RNA sequences recognized by the protein and characterize the Zn(II) binding domains NZF-1 and MyT1 and identify their DNA target sequences. This work should facilitate a molecular level understanding of the these protein-nucleic acid interactions.

Zinc Finger (ZF) proteins contain modular domains that coordinate zinc ions using a combination of four cysteine and/or histidine ligands to fold into specific three-dimensional structures. ZFs have critically important roles in modulating transcription and translation in all eukaryotes and show a remarkable capacity for highly selective nucleic acid recognition. While much is known about the metal-mediated folding and nucleic acid recognition properties of classical ZF proteins, very little is known about the biochemical mechanisms of the non-classical ZF proteins to be studied in this proposal. These studies aim to provide information on why Nature selects classical versus non-classical ZFs for a particular transcriptional and translational regulatory role. There is the potential for broader scientific impact on modes by which metal co-factored regulatory proteins operate in general. The graduate, undergraduate and high school students involved in the project will receive interdisciplinary training at the chemistry/molecular biology interface. There is a significant outreach component, particularly directed toward encouraging women to enter the STEM disciplines. This includes interaction with girls from a local high school and women from a local women's college, as well as female graduate students on the project. A "zinc finger lab" for high school girls enrolled in AP Biology is being developed.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Zinc, the second most abundant metal in biology, plays two key roles. Zinc can serve as a co-factor for enzymes or as a structural co-factor. This project focused on proteins that use zinc for the latter role: as a structural co-factor. These proteins are called ‘zinc finger’ or ZFs. ZFs are highly abundant (e.g. genomes annotate 3-10% of human proteins as ZFs); however, most have not been characterized biochemically. ZFs play important biological roles, including in RNA processing, viral replication, cell metastasis and neuronal development, therefore it is important to understand their mechanisms of action.

 

In this current work, our group focused on deciphering the mechanisms of action for three ZF proteins: cleavage and polyadenylation specificity factor 30 (CPSF30), neural zinc finger factor 1 (NZF-1) and myelin transcription factor 1 (MyT1). Our work on CPSF30 concentrated on identifying its biological target. We discovered that CPSF30 binds to pre-mRNA via an interaction between the ZF domains of CPSF30 and a conserved adenine/uracil stretch found in all pre-mRNA. These findings provided the first in vitro evidence for a role for CPSF30 in RNA regulation. We also made the exciting discovery that CPF30 contains an iron-sulfur co-factor which challenged the paradigm that ZFs contain only zinc. In other work, we identified DNA targets for NZF-1 and MyT1 and identified key hydrogen bonding interactions that govern their oligonucleotide recognition. These findings allowed us to propose a mechanism for DNA recognition by these proteins involved in neuronal development. Our current work also included the design and synthesis of RNA sensors based upon the RNA binding ZF protein tristetraprolin (TTP), and the preparation of ZF based ribonucleases. In addition, our laboratory developed Inductively Coupled Plasma Mass Spectrometry (ICP-MS) as a tool to measure metal speciation in biological systems, and collaborated with numerous laboratories both at Maryland and in the Mid-Atlantic to apply this methodology to metallobiochemical problems.

 

Our research provided key insights into the fundamental mechanisms of metalloprotein regulated RNA and DNA binding. These findings were disseminated in publications and presentations leading to the advancement of scientific knowledge. Our work to develop ICP-MS as a tool to measure metal ion levels in biological systems enhanced infrastructure. Graduate students, undergraduate students and high school students (most of whom were women) participated in the research. A yearly outreach program, ‘Spring into Maryland Science’ or SIMSI, which is a partnership with a local Women’s college, Notre Dame of Maryland, was organized. SIMSI included mini-graduate school experiences, summer research opportunities, a ‘Women in Science’ panel and a ‘Metals in your Midst’ workshop. The PI also designed summer experiences for high school girls and participated in the Maryland STEM career day with her graduate students. These efforts are part of a commitment to encouraging STEM careers for Women.
